title: Title: Justice Department launches grand jury probe of N.Y. Attorney General Letitia James
teaser: Teaser: New York Attorney General Letitia James speaks during a press conference on Jan. 8. The Justice Department has opened an investigation into James' office over its civil fraud case against President Trump.Michael M. Santiago/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: PoliticsJustice Department launches grand jury probe of N.Y. Attorney General Letitia JamesJames prosecuted the president and his companies, winning millions in fines linked to fraud allegations. Her attorney called the probe "an attack on the rule of law."

title: Title: He built Michigan's Medicaid work requirement system. Now he's warning other states
teaser: Teaser: An attendee holds a "Stop The Health Care Cuts" sign during a town hall in Lansing, Michigan, on June 6. Republicans are betting they can win the semantic battle over the future of Medicaid, with a multi-trillion dollar tax bill at stake, while Democrats view the cuts as a welcome talking point to attack the president's agenda. Title: A woman who killed her in-laws with toxic mushrooms allegedly poisoned her spouse too
teaser: Teaser: Erin Patterson, pictured in August 2023, was convicted of poisoning her estranged husband's family members with death cap mushrooms in a trial that ended last month.Marta Pascual Juanola/The Age via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: WorldA woman who killed her in-laws with toxic mushrooms allegedly poisoned her spouse tooErin Patterson was convicted last month of killing her estranged husband's relatives with a meal laced with toxic mushrooms. Newly unsealed evidence alleges she previously poisoned his meals too.

title: Title: 'Invisible battles': two years post-fire, Maui survivors struggle with mental health
teaser: Teaser: A memorial near the Lahaina Bypass highway includes photos of victims of the August 2023 wildfire.Tori DeJournett/HPRhide caption
body: Body: 'Invisible battles': two years post-fire, Maui survivors struggle with mental healthHawai‘i Public RadioThe University of Hawaiʻi's Maui Wildfire Exposure Study found that almost half of adults are still living in temporary housing, and a quarter remain unemployed despite trying to find work.

title: Title: Texas Rep. Gene Wu calls Gov. Abbott's push to oust him from office 'meaningless'
teaser: Teaser: Democratic Texas Rep. Gene Wu, center, speaks with the media following a press conference with other Texas House Democrats and Democratic members of Congress at the Democratic Party in Warrenville, Ill., Monday, Aug. 4.Nam Y. Huh/APhide caption
body: Body: Interview highlightsTexas Rep. Gene Wu calls Gov. Abbott's push to oust him from office 'meaningless'Texas State Rep. Gene Wu, who fled the state with other Democrats to stop a GOP redistricting plan, is being targeted for removal from office by Gov. Greg Abbott. Wu says Abbott lacks that power.

title: Title: No title found
Title: PJ Harvey: Tiny Desk Concert
teaser: Teaser: PJ Harvey: Tiny Desk Concert
body: Body: PJ Harvey: Tiny Desk ConcertOn her own artistic plane, PJ Harvey invites listeners to take their time to fully join her.

title: Title: Germany halts its military exports that Israel could use in Gaza
teaser: Teaser: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz attends a news conference after a meeting with Jordan's King Abdullah II at the chancellery in Berlin, July 29.Ebrahim Noroozi/APhide caption
body: Body: Middle East conflictGermany halts its military exports that Israel could use in GazaGermany will stop exporting military equipment to Israel that could be used in the Gaza Strip, in a swift response to Israel's decision to expand its operations in the Palestinian enclave's main city.

title: Title: EPA plans to end a program that makes solar power available to low-income Americans
teaser: Teaser: GRID Alternatives employees install no-cost solar panels on the rooftop of a low-income household on October 19, 2023 in Pomona, California.Mario Tama/Getty Images North Americahide caption
body: Body: ClimateEPA plans to end a program that makes solar power available to low-income AmericansThe Trump administration plans to end a $7 billion Biden-era program that helps low-income households get solar power.

title: Title: Trump wants a new U.S. census to exclude people here illegally. It'd be unprecedented
teaser: Teaser: Demonstrators rally outside the U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., in 2019 to protest the first Trump administration's failed push to add a question about a person's U.S. citizenship status to 2020 census forms.Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: PoliticsTrump wants a new U.S. census to exclude people here illegally. It'd be unprecedentedPresident Trump is calling for a "new" census that excludes people in the U.S. without legal status. The 14th Amendment requires the "whole number of persons in each state" in a key set of census results.

title: Title: No title found
Title: The laughs land in 'The Naked Gun' reboot, but fall flat in 'Freakier Friday'
teaser: Teaser: Jamie Lee Curtis, left, and Lindsay Lohan as Tess and Anna Coleman inFreakier Friday.Glen Wilson/Disney Enterprises, Inc.hide caption
body: Body: ReviewMovie ReviewsThe laughs land in 'The Naked Gun' reboot, but fall flat in 'Freakier Friday'The new Naked Gun film, starring Liam Neeson, captures its predecessors' slapstick spirit. Freakier Friday, meanwhile, proves less compelling, despite a solid performance by Lindsey Lohan.

title: Title: No title found
Title: What was with all those teen heartthrob Bobbys in the '60s?
teaser: Teaser: In the 1960s, hearthrobs named Bobby wereeverywhere.Clockwise from top left: Bobby Darin, Bobby Vee, Bobby Rydell, Bobby Goldsboro, Bobby Womack, Bobby ShermanKeystone/Getty Images; Central Press/Hulton Archive/Getty Images; Keystone/Hulton Archive/Getty Images; Hulton Archive/Getty Images; Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images; Alan Kent/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: CultureWhat was with all those teen heartthrob Bobbys in the '60s?Bobbys were inescapable in music in the '50s and '60s: Bobby Sherman, Bobby Rydell, Bobby Darin and more. NPR critic Bob Mondello looks back to an era when everyone seemed to share his name.

title: Title: 'What Dan Read': What a reading list of 3,599 books tells us about a library superfan
teaser: Teaser: Some of Dan Pelzer's book recommendations on display.Courtesy of Columbus Metropolitan Libraryhide caption
body: Body: 'What Dan Read': What a reading list of 3,599 books tells us about a library superfanWBURA public library in Ohio is celebrating the life of one of its most loyal patrons, a retired social worker named Dan Pelzer.

title: Title: Trump is open to meeting with Putin for peace talks without Zelenskyy
teaser: Teaser: This combination of photos shows Russian President Vladimir Putin (left) in Moscow on May 9, and President Trump in Washington on Aug. 1.Alexander Zemlianichenko and Mark Schiefelbein/APhide caption
body: Body: Ukraine invasion — explainedTrump is open to meeting with Putin for peace talks without ZelenskyyThe discussion of a summit came amid the countdown to President Trump's Friday deadline for Russia to agree to a ceasefire with Ukraine or face new sanctions and tariffs on Russian energy exports.

title: Title: No title found
Title: AI-generated music is here to stay. Will streaming services like Spotify label it?
teaser: Teaser: Unlike other tech giants — including YouTube, Meta and Tiktok — Spotify is not currently taking steps to label AI-generated content.NurPhoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images/NurPhotohide caption
body: Body: MusicAI-generated music is here to stay. Will streaming services like Spotify label it?Unlike other tech giants, many music-streaming services like Spotify are not currently taking steps to label AI-generated content. But experts say more transparency is key.

title: Title: Photos of a starving baby in Gaza shocked the world. Here's how he's doing now
body: Body: Middle East conflictPhotos of a starving baby in Gaza shocked the world. Here's how he's doing nowImages showing baby Mohammad Al-Motawaq captured world attention last month. In Israel, they were used to support claims that mass hunger in Gaza does not exist.

title: Title: No title found
Title: A word is born — and critiqued: 'healthocide'
teaser: Teaser: A view of the destroyed al-Shifa hospital in Gaza City on September 17, 2024, amid the ongoing war between Israel and the Palestinian Hamas group. The hospital was once the crown jewel of Gaza's medical community.Omar Al-Qattaa/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: Goats and SodaA word is born — and critiqued: 'healthocide'This week a new word made its public debut. With an increase in attacks on health care facilities and personnel, the goal of this coinage is to spark outrage and outcry. But the reaction is mixed.

title: Title: Hundreds of children disappeared in Argentina. Their grandmothers united to find them
teaser: Teaser: Haley Cohen Gilliland's A Flower Traveled in My Blood tells the story of a group of grandmothers who spent decades searching for their stolen grandchildren during and after Argentina's "Dirty War."
body: Body: ReviewBook ReviewsHundreds of children disappeared in Argentina. Their grandmothers united to find themHaley Cohen Gilliland's A Flower Traveled in My Blood tells the story of a group of grandmothers who spent decades searching for their stolen grandchildren during and after Argentina's "Dirty War."

title: Title: Video shows Department of Justice official urging Jan. 6 rioters to 'kill' cops
teaser: Teaser: A screenshot of Jared Wise joining the crowd at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021.Department of Justice/Screenshot by NPRhide caption
body: Body: ExclusiveInvestigationsVideo shows Department of Justice official urging Jan. 6 rioters to 'kill' copsThe Department of Justice hired a former Jan. 6 defendant who was caught on tape urging rioters to "kill" police. The department calls him a "valued member" of the administration.

title: Title: No title found
Title: 13 podcast episodes to make back-to-school season easier on kids and parents
teaser: Teaser: The new school year can be exciting, but also stressful. Kids may be feeling anxious. Parents may be juggling new responsibilities. Experts share tips on how to manage this season of change.
body: Body: Life Kit13 podcast episodes to make back-to-school season easier on kids and parentsThe new school year can be exciting, but also stressful. Kids may be feeling anxious. Parents may be juggling new responsibilities. Experts share tips on how to manage this season of change.

title: Title: Trump's tariffs are now fully in effect. Are prices rising? Here's what we know
teaser: Teaser: A family shops in Princeton, N.J. Tariffs are only starting to affect prices on store shelves.Matt Slocum/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: EconomyTrump's tariffs are now fully in effect. Are prices rising? Here's what we knowPrices have risen a bit, but companies have been finding ways to delay price increases — for now.

title: Title: Meet the judge hearing Harvard's lawsuits against the Trump administration
teaser: Teaser: U.S. District Court Judge Allison Burroughs appears at her Senate confirmation hearing in 2014.Courtesy of U.S. Senate Judiciary Committeehide caption
body: Body: LawMeet the judge hearing Harvard's lawsuits against the Trump administrationWBURU.S. District Judge Allison Burroughs is presiding over two Harvard cases challenging Trump's moves to cut federal funding from the university and to ban it from enrolling international students.

title: Title: No title found
Title: Trump orders colleges to share admissions data, with an eye on affirmative action
teaser: Teaser: College in the US.LA Johnson/NPRhide caption
body: Body: EducationTrump orders colleges to share admissions data, with an eye on affirmative actionThursday's move would compel colleges to report more data about the students they enroll and those who apply, including applicants' race and standardized test scores.

title: Title: After nearly 24 years, NYC officials identify 3 more 9/11 victims
teaser: Teaser: Michael Keating, center in the second row, stands during the wreath laying at the 9/11 memorial at the Boston Public Garden. His mother, Barbara Ann Keating, was killed during the September 11th attacks in 2001. September 11, 2016.MediaNews Group/Boston Herald vi/MediaNews Group via Getty Images/MediaNews Group RMhide caption
body: Body: NationalAfter nearly 24 years, NYC officials identify 3 more 9/11 victimsUsing advanced DNA-analysis techniques researchers in New York City identified three more victims of the 9/11 terror attacks that occurred nearly 24 years ago.

title: Title: No title found
Title: Federal judge halts construction at Florida's 'Alligator Alcatraz'
teaser: Teaser: President President Donald Trump (second from left), Florida Governor Ron DeSantis (L), and Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem (R) tour a migrant detention center, dubbed "Alligator Alcatraz," located at the site of the Dade-Collier Training and Transition Airport in Ochopee, Fla. on July 1, 2025.Andrew Caballero-Reynolds/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: NationalFederal judge halts construction at Florida's 'Alligator Alcatraz'The 14-day stoppage comes as a federal judge considers whether additional construction of the immigration detention facility in south Florida's Everglades is detrimental to the environment.

title: Title: Trump administration cuts McGruff the Crime Dog's fentanyl campaign
teaser: Teaser: A McGruff the Crime Dog public service ad warning young people of fake prescription drugs that may contain fentanyl.National Crime Prevention Council/YouTube/Screenshot by NPRhide caption
body: Body: PoliticsTrump administration cuts McGruff the Crime Dog's fentanyl campaignThe National Crime Prevention Council is questioning federal cuts to McGruff the Crime Dog's campaign to sniff out fake pills. The group says McGruff's work that started in 1980 isn't over.

title: Title: Ultra-processed food consumption is down a bit, but still more than 50% of U.S. diet
teaser: Teaser: There isn't a standard definition of ultra-processed foods, but all the foods pictured fit the bill. They contain added fat, sugar or salt, plus preservatives to extend their shelf-life.Dan Kitwood/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: Shots - Health NewsUltra-processed food consumption is down a bit, but still more than 50% of U.S. dietAmericans get about 55% of our calories from tasty, cheap — and unhealthy — manufactured foods, the latest data from CDC says. For kids, the percentage is even higher.

title: Title: No title found
Title: Haiti inaugurates new leadership as gangs threaten to overthrow the government
teaser: Teaser: Laurent Saint-Cyr (left) attends the ceremony for his appointment as president of the Transitional Council in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, Thursday.Odelyn Joseph/APhide caption
body: Body: The AmericasHaiti inaugurates new leadership as gangs threaten to overthrow the governmentBusinessman Laurent Saint-Cyr became the head of Haiti's transitional presidential council tasked with restoring order as gangs underscored the challenges facing the Caribbean nation.

title: Title: Federal records contradict what FEMA leader told Congress about Texas flood response
teaser: Teaser: Search and recovery crews remove debris from the bank of the Guadalupe River on July 9, 2025 in Center Point, Texas, after deadly flash floods. Most calls made between July 6th and July 9th to FEMA call centers went unanswered, according to call logs kept by the agency.Jim Vondruska/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: ExclusiveClimateFederal records contradict what FEMA leader told Congress about Texas flood responseFunding for FEMA's disaster survivor hotline lapsed the day after the Texas floods, federal records show. It took DHS Secretary Kristi Noem five days to approve more money.

title: Title: Trump wants a new U.S. census to exclude people here illegally. It'd be unprecedented
teaser: Teaser: Demonstrators rally outside the U.S. Supreme Court in Washington, D.C., in 2019 to protest the first Trump administration's failed push to add a question about a person's U.S. citizenship status to 2020 census forms.Mandel Ngan/AFP via Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: PoliticsTrump wants a new U.S. census to exclude people here illegally. It'd be unprecedentedPresident Trump is calling for a "new" census that excludes people in the U.S. without legal status. The 14th Amendment requires the "whole number of persons in each state" in a key set of census results.

title: Title: A word is born — and critiqued: 'healthocide'

body: Body: Goats and SodaA word is born — and critiqued: 'healthocide'This week a new word made its public debut. With an increase in attacks on health care facilities and personnel, the goal of this coinage is to spark outrage and outcry. But the reaction is mixed.

body: Body: NationalFederal judge halts construction at Florida's 'Alligator Alcatraz'The 14-day stoppage comes as a federal judge considers whether additional construction of the immigration detention facility in south Florida's Everglades is detrimental to the environment.

body: Body: Shots - Health NewsUltra-processed food consumption is down a bit, but still more than 50% of U.S. dietAmericans get about 55% of our calories from tasty, cheap — and unhealthy — manufactured foods, the latest data from CDC says. For kids, the percentage is even higher.

title: Title: Federal records contradict what FEMA leader told Congress about Texas flood response
teaser: Teaser: Search and recovery crews remove debris from the bank of the Guadalupe River on July 9, 2025 in Center Point, Texas, after deadly flash floods. Most calls made between July 6th and July 9th to FEMA call centers went unanswered, according to call logs kept by the agency.Jim Vondruska/Getty Imageshide caption
body: Body: ExclusiveClimateFederal records contradict what FEMA leader told Congress about Texas flood responseFunding for FEMA's disaster survivor hotline lapsed the day after the Texas floods, federal records show. It took DHS Secretary Kristi Noem five days to approve more money.
